Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) is a four-year degree program offered by the college. Students are required to complete Years 3 and 4 to receive their Bachelor's degree in Construction Management. The program combines theoretical knowledge, applied research, field study, and practical education. It offers a blend of studies in construction engineering and technology with business and management methods.

Students gain knowledge and skills to manage construction projects from start to finish and master construction-related technical disciplines and soft skills. Upon graduation, students receive the academic credential designation of Hons. B.Tech (Construction Management). The program is recognized by the construction industry and fully accredited by the Canadian Institute of Quantity Surveyors (CIQS).

Graduates qualify to obtain Gold Seal Certification (GSC) from the Canadian Construction Association (CCA) in various roles like certified superintendents, forepeople, estimators, project managers, owner's construction managers, and safety practitioners.

The program requires a mandatory field experience semester in the third year, where students must complete a minimum of 450 hours of fieldwork experience or its equivalent. Students can register for the Field Experience course (TCOP 1001) or seek prior learning assessment recognition (PLAR) if they have past field experience.

Career options for graduates include various roles in the construction industry like project managers, estimators, and safety practitioners.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T317 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program at the college prepares students for leadership roles in the construction industry. Graduates may find career opportunities as construction managers, project managers, project coordinators, field engineers, site superintendents, estimators, project monitors, building science specialists, building condition assessors, construction sales managers, construction claims specialists, construction quality control specialists, construction health and safety specialists, construction cost consultants, developers, project controls specialists, site inspectors, contractors, or subcontractors.

The construction management industry requires professionals with multidisciplinary knowledge and skills to coordinate teams and liaise with stakeholders. Construction managers plan, organize, lead, and control projects from start to finish, focusing on sustainable construction techniques and practices.

The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program is fully accredited by the Canadian Institute of Quantity Surveyors (CIQS), the Chartered Institute of Building (CIOB), and the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). Graduates are qualified to obtain professional memberships in various construction management associations, such as CIQS or Construction Estimator Certified (CEC) designation, and the Gold Seal Certification (GSC) offered by the Canadian Construction Association (CCA). However, membership applications must be submitted separately.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T317 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Canadian Construction Association (CCA) offers Gold Seal Certification for various roles in the construction industry including superintendents, forepeople, estimators, project managers, owner’s construction managers, and safety practitioners. This certification is based on a candidate's education, training, and professional work experience.

George Brown College offers an Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree which is well respected in the construction sector. Industry leaders including Temple Harris, vice-chairman, Gillam Group; Christopher Rick, PCL Constructors, Canada Inc.; James Zippel, general manager, Electrical Service & Projects, Ainsworth; and Greg Kozicz, president, Alberici Constructors, Ltd., have expressed the importance of having properly trained construction professionals and the need for improved education and training in the industry. Michael George, president, Trisura Insurance, also emphasized the urgency for a program of this nature due to the rapid change and technology-driven nature of the construction industry.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T317 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program graduates qualify for graduate studies in relevant fields. Some recent graduates have pursued further studies at universities such as University of Waterloo, Columbia University, and Toronto Metropolitan University.

Required courses for the Construction Management program include:
- BLDG 2114: Construction Estimating 2 – Pricing (semester 4)
- BLDG 2111: Highrise Construction Technology (semester 5)
- BLDG 2166: Construction Graphics 2 (semester 5)
- BLDG 3025: Construction Estimating 3 – Bidding (semester 5)
- BLDG 3041: Mechanical and Electrical Construction Practices (semester 5)
- BLDG 3055: Work Term Preparation 1 (semester 5)
- BSCI 3101: Applications in Building Science (semester 5)
- BLDG 1162: Building Code Act and Regulations (semester 6)
- BLDG 3167: Construction Cost Control (semester 6)
- BLDG 3168: Capstone 1 – Bid Competition (semester 6)
- BLDG 3169: Work Term Preparation 2 (semester 6)
- BLDG 3175: Heavy Construction 2 (semester 6)
- ECON 2005: Macro and Micro Economics (semester 6)
- MGMT 3150: Construction Project Management 2 - Contract Administration (semester 6)
- Liberal Studies Elective (select one, semester 6)
- TCOP1001: Work Term (450 hours) (summer field experience semester)
- BLDG 3152: Economics of Project Development (semester 7)
- BLDG 3170: Preconstruction Cost Planning (semester 7)
- BLDG 3177: Application in Building Information Modeling (BIM) (semester 7)
- BLDG 3178: Decision Analysis and Critical Thinking (semester 7)
- BLDG 4020: Research Methods (semester 8)
- MGMT 4050: Construction Project Procurement 1 (semester 8)
- MGMT 4055: Construction Labour Relations and Human Resources (semester 8)
- MGMT 4088: Construction Business Management and Entrepreneurship (semester 8)

Mike Van Volsen is an operations manager at Access Suspended Platforms Inc. and has refined skills in both technical and managerial aspects of construction.

Context:
Program Offered: Construction Business Management and Entrepreneurship
Semester 8 Courses:
- BLDG 4021: Construction Risk Management
- BLDG 4050: Sustainable Construction
- BLDG 4150: Capstone 2 – Industry Research
- MGMT 4052: Project Financial Monitoring
- MGMT 4090: Construction Procurement 2
- MGMT 4091: Leadership and Ethics for Construction Managers

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Use relevant media to communicate construction project information
- Analyze past performance of construction projects
- Manage construction projects in a compliant, safe, ethical and sustainable manner
- Apply management tools and techniques to execute construction projects on time and within budget
- Recognize and value diversity in executing construction projects
- Incorporate effective leadership strategies
- Apply principles and practices of leadership development and human resources management
- Analyze technical problems encountered in construction projects
- Apply business, accounting and financial principles and practices to manage construction project costs
- Evaluate potential risks impacting construction projects
- Create technical documents relevant to the design, procurement and execution of construction projects
- Behave ethically and responsibly in accordance with professional codes of conduct, laws, policies and contracts

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $9,418.00 *
- International (missing)

* An additional field experience fee applies for the field experience semester.
For more information, contact construction\_degree@georgebrown.ca or call 416-415-5000, ext. 6297.

Context:
Program Offered: Civil Engineering Technology (Applied Degree)

Tuition Fees:
- Domestic Students: $9,418.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 and Fall 2024 (does not include Field Experience cost).
- International Students: $20,925.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 and Fall 2024.

Additional Costs: Estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters.

Financial Assistance: The program is approved for OSAP funding for students who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements:
- Applicants must be graduates of an Ontario College Advanced (three-year) diploma in Civil Engineering Technology.
- Graduates must have a GPA of 3.0 or higher.

Special Requirements: Students are strongly recommended to own or purchase a laptop with specifications as follows: operating system: Windows 10 Home 64-bit English, processor: 9th Generation Intel® Core™ i7-9750H (12MB Cache, up to 4.5 GHz, 6 cores), memory (RAM): 16GB (2x8GB DDR4 2666MHz), disk space: 256GB M, and arrange for home Internet service with 25 to 40 Mbps and a ping time of 20–100 ms.

George Brown College has been granted a consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities to offer this applied degree for a seven-year term starting May 7, 2018.

Disclaimer: The information is subject to change without notice and should not be considered as a representation or warranty. Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.
